post.html:
The research will be an attempt to explore the potential of user interface and human centered design for sustaining a consolidated democratic future. Taking the feasible scale of a master’s thesis into account, the exploration is narrowed down to a core question: How to design interactive argument diagram for democratic communication?

The world is currently suffering a decline of democracy. User interface and experience have an unevenly important impact on this ongoing crisis. The digital democratic communication is truly one of the most prominent types of practice which has a great diversity within, whereas filter bubble has also become a trendy word describing the ubiquitous silos created by groups of like-minded people online.

The research will be an attempt to explore the potential of user interface and human centered design for sustaining a consolidated democratic future. Taking the feasible scale of a master’s thesis into account, the exploration is narrowed down to a core question: How to design interactive argument diagram for democratic communication?

Two examples of interactive argument diagram: Kialo (left) and Pol.is (right)

The overall methodology is a mixture of research through and for design. The research process will comprise the following activities: interview, case study, quantitative research, and co-creation.

The expected outcomes of this research are listed below:

A series of test that carries out the pros and cons of existing systems of argument diagramming A novel design of argument diagramming for a better democratic outcome An exploration on how to involve behavior tracking technique and quantitative analysis in human-centered design research and in experimental political sciences A theoretical exploration on what democratic value of design should be and how to operationalize it in an empirical and constructive design research
